Executive Summary:
Mammoth cmmunity Water District Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Poicies:  The Mammoth Community Water District Provides water treatment service to the Town of Mammoth Lakes, California.  The service area is located at an elevation of approximately 8,000feet on the eastern sides of the Sierra Nevada mountain range.  The town is surrounded by the United States Forest Service lands and is heavily utilized as a recreational area.

The district has institued a Risk Management Program to ensure that its facilities utilizing regulated hazardous chemical substances are opeated accroding to the rules established by the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

Through its risk management program the District has perfromed a hazard assessment to assess the potential effects of an accidental release of a hazardous substance.  This assessment includes perfroming an off-site consequence analysis including analysis of a worst-case scenario and one alternative release scenario.

The Dsitrict has established a prevention program to prevent accidental releases of regulated hazardous chemical substances.  This program includes safety precautions and maintenance, monitoring and emplee safety training.

A response program has also been established that requires specific action to be taken in emergency situations.  This includes procedures for notifying public and local agenicies responsible for responding to accidental releases, and employee response training measures.

The District utilizes one regulated substance in its water treatment operations.  This substance is chlorine gas, which is utilzed for disinfection purposes.

The treatment process at the facility include filtration through multi-media filter vessels and disinfection of the filtered water through injection of chlorine gas.  Water is then distributed to the community for domestic use.  Chlorine is stored at this facility in steel cylinders, each containing 2,000 lbs of gas.

General Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Specific prevention steps that the District has taken include a computerized alarm system that immediately notifies emergency personnel of potential chemical release situations.  Minimal amounts of chlorine gas in the atmosphere will trigger on-site alarms and provide notification.  District personnel also receive specific training in the handling of chlorine cylinders and apparatus.  Only necessary amounts of chlorine required for use in the treatment processes is stored at the water facility to mninimize the potential hazards.  New equipment added to the system are automatic shutof valves on the chlorine cylinder tanks to shut down the accidental release of chlorine.

                     Five Year History-None

                     Emergency Repsonse Program

The District relies upon the emergency services of the fire department community hazardous materials response team in the even of a catastrophic release of chlorine.  District personnel have been trained to respond to accidental relase of chlorine.
